question: A single-level directory allows multiple users to have their own separate directories.
In a two-level directory structure, each user has their own directory and cannot access other users' directories by default.
A tree-structured directory allows the creation of subdirectories inside directories.
One disadvantage of a tree-structured directory is that file searching may take longer.
In a single-level directory, there is no possibility of filename conflicts.
In a two-level directory, all users share a common directory where they store their files.
The root directory in a tree-structured directory is the topmost directory that contains all other directories.
In a disk, tracks are divided into sectors that store data.
A hard disk consists of a single platter used for data storage.
The read/write head in a disk is responsible for reading and writing data on the platters.
Logical structure of a disk refers to how data is physically arranged on the platters.
NTFS and EXT4 are examples of logical structures used for file systems.
A boot block stores important startup information required for the operating system to boot.
RAID stands for Random Access Independent Disks.
RAID 0 provides data redundancy, ensuring data safety in case of disk failure.
RAID 1 mirrors data across two disks, providing a backup in case of failure.
RAID 5 uses distributed parity to store error correction data across multiple disks.
RAID 6 offers double parity, allowing the system to recover even if two disks fail.
RAID 2 is commonly used because of its high efficiency and reliability.
RAID 4 uses block-level striping with a dedicated parity disk.
RAID 3 and RAID 4 are identical in terms of data storage.
In RAID 5, there is a dedicated parity disk.
RAID structures improve speed, reliability, and storage capacity.
RAID 0 is primarily used for backup purposes.
A single-level directory is more efficient for large-scale file organization than a tree-structured directory.
RAID 1 is the best choice when data redundancy is required.
The superblock contains metadata about the disk and file system.
A file control block (FCB) stores information about a file, such as size and permissions.
In a single-level directory, files from different users are stored in separate directories.
RAID 6 is faster than RAID 0 because of its double parity system.
Data stored in RAID 1 is lost if one of the disks fails.
A tree-structured directory can have multiple root directories.
RAID structures can be used in both home and enterprise environments.
In RAID 5, losing two disks results in complete data loss.
The physical structure of a disk affects how quickly data can be accessed.
RAID 0 is a good choice for gaming PCs where speed is the priority.
In a two-level directory, a userâ€™s files can be accessed by other users without restrictions.
File organization is an important aspect of storage management in operating systems.
RAID 3 is commonly used in modern computer systems.
A two-level directory is less secure than a single-level directory.
RAID 5 provides both speed and fault tolerance.
Data stored in RAID 1 is lost permanently if one disk fails.
NTFS is an example of a physical disk structure.
Sectors are smaller subdivisions of tracks on a disk platter.
RAID improves storage performance but does not offer redundancy.
RAID 6 is more fault-tolerant than RAID 5.
The logical structure of a disk is determined by the file system in use.
In a single-level directory, file access is faster than in a tree-structured directory.
RAID 1 requires a minimum of three disks for implementation.
RAID technology is only used in enterprise-level storage solutions.
